Grand Forks Library Site Traffic Analysis                                                    Grand Forks, ND


EXECUTIVE SUMMARY


The purpose of this report is to document the results of traffic impact analyses conducted for a proposed
library expansion or relocation at three locations in Grand Forks, ND. All three locations are on or
adjacent to South Washington Street, a local principal arterial. The location of the three sites is as
follows:

Site A: Existing library location (proposed remodel and expansion).
Site B: Proposed library location on east side of South Washington Street between 7th and 8th Avenues S
formerly the home of Leevers County Market.
Site C: Proposed library location east of S 11th Street and north of planned wellness center development.

As directed by the City of Grand Forks Engineering Department, all relevant intersections adjacent to
each study site as well as each driveway associated with the new or expanded library site were evaluated
for LOS (Level of Service). LOS was determined for each study intersection to provide insight as to how
the intersections are currently operating in terms of capacity. Capacity analysis was based on the 2000
Highway Capacity Manual (HCM) using Synchro traffic simulation models. As standard to the City of
Grand Forks Engineering Department, a LOS of "C" or better is required at all study intersections during
all analysis periods.




                              Site A                             Site B                          Site C




FIGURE 1 ­ Study Limits and Intersections

First, LOS was determined at each study intersection under existing conditions. To determine the existing
conditions, an inventory of the transportation network was conducted where number of lanes, facility
type, area type, transit service data, and traffic control data was collected. It is important to note that all
driveways were analyzed as stop control due to the inherent nature of these approaches. Additionally,
stop control was assumed on the southbound approach of the T-Intersection of Library Circle for analysis
purposes. These baseline data provided the basis for assessing the roadway facilities. Existing traffic
volume data was provided by the Grand Forks-East Grand Forks Metropolitan Planning Organization or
estimated by the City of Grand Forks. This data included traffic volumes and turning movement counts.
The peak-hour turning movements were normalized into average peak hour movements by applying
conversions factors derived from the North Dakota 2008 Traffic Report prepared by the NDDOT.

Kadrmas Lee & Jackson                                                                                     Page ii
Grand Forks Library Site Traffic Analysis                                                   Grand Forks, ND



The overall objective of this study was to show what effect the expanded or proposed library will have on
the transportation system. In general, the critical traffic time period for any new development is directly
associated with the peaking characteristics of both the site-generated trips and commuter travel patterns.
Due to the inherent nature of library traffic volumes, the time period correlating with the highest
cumulative directional traffic demands was determined to be the P.M. peak hour of adjacent street traffic
and was thus selected for analysis.

Next, background traffic conditions were analyzed for the anticipated year of full Library build-out
without the library-generated trips (year 2013). First impacts of committed transportation improvements
during the forecast period were considered to account for any change in travel patterns. The City of
Grand Forks Engineering Department currently anticipates the extension of South 11th Street from 40th
Avenue South to 44th Avenue South at Site C before 2013. As a result, trip reassignment was conducted
to estimate use of this roadway by existing traffic.

The background traffic conditions forecasts include through traffic consisting of all movements through
the study area, without either an origin or a destination in the study area and traffic generated by all other
developments in the study area with an origin and/or destination in the study area. Next, to determine the
regional traffic through the study area, the trend or growth method was utilized based on historic data. In
consultation with the City of Grand Forks Engineering Department, a conservatively high 2% growth rate
was applied to all arterials supporting regional travel. Finally, approved development was considered to
determine if any new traffic is anticipated within the study area. The City of Grand Forks Engineering
Department has approved a Wellness Center and Ice Arena to be developed adjacent to Site C. Sites A
and B are located in fully developed areas and as a result, have no planned or approved developments
within the study limits. It is important to note that due to the relatively low number of trips by transit,
cycling and walking, the combined mode split was assumed to be zero (i.e. 100% automobile trips).

ITE Trip Generation was utilized to estimate the one-directional travel movements with either an origin or
destination to the specified land uses. Next, the traffic expected to be generated by the developments was
distributed and assigned to the roadway system so that the impact of the new developments on roadway
links could be analyzed. To determine the trip distributions, the roadway network (via the Grand
Forks/East Grand Forks MPO Functional Classification Map), surrounding land uses (via the City of
Grand Forks Planning Department's Zoning Map), and location of competing developments (National
Independent Health Club Association for Wellness Center competition and Grand Forks Park District for
Ice Arena competition) were reviewed. Once trip distributions were estimated, trip assignment was
considered to determine which routes each trip will utilize within the roadway network. Based on logical
routings, available roadway capacities, left turns at critical intersections and projected and perceived
relative travel times, traffic assignment was estimated. It should be noted that the purpose of this study
was to perform a comparative evaluation of potential library sites. As a result, trip generation,
distribution and assignment regarding the wellness center and ice area were based on data readily
available for inclusion in the study. It is anticipated that detailed traffic analysis of the wellness center
site may likely produce different results.

Once the background traffic conditions were estimated and analyzed, library trips were generated using
ITE Trip Generation for the same future year of 2013. Trip distribution was estimated using data
provided by the Grand Forks Public Library Study Needs Assessment produced by Library Consulting,
P.A (November 23, 2009). It was assumed that the overall trip distribution patterns are generally the
same for each of the three library sites. Once trip distributions were estimated, trip assignment was
considered to determine which routes each trip will utilize in the roadway network using the technique
outlined for the wellness center and ice arena.


Kadrmas Lee & Jackson                                                                                 Page iii
 Grand Forks Library Site Traffic Analysis                                                                          Grand Forks, ND


 Finally, as standard to the City of Grand Forks Engineering Department traffic impact studies, traffic
 conditions for a 5-year horizon were analyzed to assess future service levels. According to the city, no
 planned developments or system improvements are approved at any of the study sites between the year
 2013 and 2018. As a result, only through traffic was "grown" to reflect increasing traffic using a 2%
 annual growth. A graphical representation of traffic levels of service under existing, future background
 (without the library), and total future (with the library) traffic conditions for each site is shown below.
                                                     Lane Groups with LOS Worse than C

      1. SUMMARY OF KEY FINDINGS



              During the evening commuter peak hour, the new library is expected to generate approximately
              190 inbound and 206 outbound trips.

              Based on the traffic analyses performed as part of this study, all three (3) sites are expected to
              have adjacent intersections that are expected to operate below acceptable levels of service (i.e.,
              below LOS "C").

              A comparative review of the incremental impacts on the adjacent intersections resulting from
              each site are tabulated below.

TABLE 1 ­ Overall Level of Service Results
                                Ex istin g C o n d itio n s (2011)    Back gro u n d C o n d tio n s (2013)        O p e n in g D ay (2013)              Ho rizo n Ye ar (2018)

           Site                 N um ber of                            N um ber of                             N um ber of                           N um ber of
                                                   A p p ro ach e s                       A p p ro ach e s                       A p p ro ach e s                      A p p ro ach e s

         - Site B
    Lo catio n N e ar

    C e n te r - Site C


              While the traffic analysis results indicate a varying degree of impact associated with each site,
              there are other factors that may influence the final site selection process such as land use
              compatibility.    Furthermore, appropriate traffic mitigation measures (e.g., operational
              improvements) may be necessary to accommodate traffic volumes generated by the new library.




Kadrmas Lee & Jackson                                                                                                                                                       Page 1
Grand Forks Library Site Traffic Analysis                                                  Grand Forks, ND


2. STUDY SCOPE AND TECHNICAL APPROACH



This report documents the results of traffic impact analyses performed for three (3) library sites located in
the city of Grand Forks, ND. The key objective of the study was to perform an evaluation of the sites
under both existing and the projected future traffic conditions based on peak-hour levels of service. In
general, the critical traffic time period for any new development is directly associated with the peaking
characteristics of both the project-related travel and area transportation system. Due to the inherent nature
of library traffic volumes, the time period correlating with the highest cumulative directional traffic
demands was determined to be the P.M. peak hour of adjacent street traffic and was thus selected for
analysis. The sites evaluated in this study are listed below and shown on Figure 1.

        SITE A - Existing Library location (proposed remodel and expansion)

        SITE B - Proposed Redevelopment of Commercial Site (Formerly Leevers County Market)

        SITE C - Proposed New Construction within the Proposed Park District Wellness Center

The traffic impact analyses performed as part of this study were based on the latest guidelines contained
in a document provided by the city titled "Scope of Work or Traffic Impact Studies, Grand Forks
Engineering Department." These guidelines require that a level-of-service "C" or better be achieved at
study intersections during the analysis periods.

Consistent with the scope of this study, and in consultation with city staff, the following study
assumptions we incorporated within the traffic analyses:


Study Assumptions

         Proposed Library ­ The new library will consist of 62,267 square feet with approximately 25
        employees.

         Peak-Hour Traffic Analysis ­ For the purposes of this study, the traffic analyses were
        performed for the PM peak-hour conditions.

        Trip Generation - ITE Trip Generation rates (8th Edition) were used to forecast trips generated
        by the Library, Wellness Center, and Ice Arena. ITE rates associated with an Ice Arena were
        found to not be representative (due to context and sample size), as a result, trip generation rates
        for a recreational community center were used based on facility size and use and corresponding
        sample size of previous studies.

        Trip Distribution - The projected PM peak-hour trips generated by the library, Wellness Center,
        and Ice Arena were assigned to the road network based on population distributions and
        directional traffic volumes within the study area as discussed below:

        Library Trips - The directional distribution was determined based on the Library Needs Study
        produced by Library Consulting, P.A. Data provided in this study was used as the basis for trip

Kadrmas Lee & Jackson                                                                                 Page 2
Grand Forks Library Site Traffic Analysis                                                 Grand Forks, ND


        distribution patterns. It is assumed that the overall distribution patterns will remain the same for
        the three library sites.




FIGURE 3 - Location of Library Sites

        Trip distribution for the wellness center and ice arena were based on current Grand Forks
        population (used City of Grand Forks Land Use Map), roadways with the most direct route
        offering the lowest average delay (MPO Functional Classification Map), and location of
        competing businesses (National Independent Health Club Association Website for local
        fitness/health centers and Grand Forks Park District Website for local ice arenas). It should be
        noted that the purpose of this study was to perform a comparative evaluation of potential library
        sites. As a result, trip distribution regarding the wellness center and ice area was based on data



Kadrmas Lee & Jackson                                                                                Page 3
Grand Forks Library Site Traffic Analysis                                               Grand Forks, ND


        readily available for the inclusion in the study and was assumed equal for the two sites. It is
        anticipated that refinements may produce slightly different results.

        All existing turning movement counts were provided by the Grand Forks-East Grand Forks
        Metropolitan Planning Organization.

        For the remaining intersections without current turning movement counts, the city of Grand Forks
        Engineering Department provided data that was employed to estimate turning movement counts.
        The city provided AADT values, turning distribution, K-values, and D-values, to estimate current
        traffic conditions. PHF for intersections without turning movement counts were assumed to be
        the Synchro standard of 0.92.

        Due to the low modal split for trips by transit, cycling and walking within the City of Grand
        Forks, the combined mode split for these modes should assume to be zero.

        Peak hour for generating library trips may differ from peak hour for adjacent street traffic. The
        peak hour of generation for the Library was not considered due to the low levels of traffic
        expected on the majority of the study intersections during nonpeak traffic hours.

        Currently the Library does not open until 9 AM. Due to the inherent nature of morning peak
        hours typically being associated with a time period between 7-9 AM, the morning peak hour was
        not considered.

        The removal of Library Circle east of the existing library Site A is assumed to cause negligible
        effects on peak-hour traffic patterns due to the nominal volume of through movements on this
        facility. According to City of Grand Forks Engineering staff, the K-Mart driveway access located
        at the intersection of Library Circle and 20th Avenue South currently serves significant amounts
        of through traffic not generated by K-Mart. If this driveway were closed, significant trip
        reassignment may be required.

        Full build out of the new or expanded library are expected to be in the year 2013 with no
        development phasing required.

        Site B will have two driveways: 1 on 8th Avenue S between S Washington Street and S 12th Street
        and the other on S 12th Street between 7th Avenue S and 8th Avenue S.

        Driveways associated with the wellness center, ice area, and proposed library location at Site C
        are depicted in Appendix C ­ Trip Distribution and Trip Assignment.

        The only roadway improvement anticipated at the three study sites is the extension of South 11th
        Street from 40th Avenue South to 44th Avenue South at Site C. Similarly the only approved
        future developments are a Wellness Center and Ice Arena near Site C. The aforementioned
        roadway improvements and future developments are anticipated to be completed by 2013.



Kadrmas Lee & Jackson                                                                             Page 4
Grand Forks Library Site Traffic Analysis                                               Grand Forks, ND


        To determine the regional traffic through the study area, the trend or growth method was utilized
        based on historic data. A conservatively high 2% growth rate was agreed upon with the City of
        Grand Forks Engineer Department and was applied to all arterials supporting regional travel.

        Stop control is assumed for all approaches exiting a driveway. Additionally, stop control was
        assumed on the southbound approach of the T-Intersection of Library Circle for analysis
        purposes.




Kadrmas Lee & Jackson                                                                             Page 5
Grand Forks Library Site Traffic Analysis                                                Grand Forks, ND


3. EXISTING TRAFFIC CONDITIONS



The existing roadway facilities providing access to each site, their functional classification, and traffic
control devices (e.g., traffic signal, stop/yield control, etc.) and intersection lane arrangements are
depicted on Figure 2. Existing turning movement counts at selected study intersections were provided by
the Grand Forks-East Grand Forks Metropolitan Planning Organization (MPO). The peak-hour turning
movements were normalized into average peak hour movements by applying conversions factors derived
from the North Dakota 2008 Traffic Report prepared by the NDDOT.

At intersections where recent turning movement count data were not readily available, P.M. peak-hour
traffic volumes were estimated based on roadway segment Average Annual Daily Traffic (AADT) values,
turning movement distributions, K-values, and D-values. Please refer to Appendix A ­ Peak PM
Turning Movement Counts for peak hour turning movement counts calculated from city of Grand Forks
data and PetraPro print outs from Grand Forks-East Grand Forks turning movement counts.

This study included only one signalized intersection located on South Washington at the intersection of
Campbell Drive. The timing plan for this intersection was provided by the Grand Forks-East Grand Forks
MPO in the form of a Synchro file. It is important to note that timing plan and coordination refinement
may result in slightly different level of service results.

Based on the intersection traffic volumes and existing geometric conditions, the study intersections were
analyzed using Synchro/SimTraffic simulation model to determine the level of service during existing
weekday evening peak traffic conditions. The results of the capacity analyses are summarized in Tables
1A through 1C. It is important to note that the tabulated results are simply outputs from Synchro capacity
analysis software. It does not represent redistributed trips due to long queues or delays. Since delay is
compounded based on queue length, it is not atypical for delay outputs to be irrational.




Kadrmas Lee & Jackson                                                                               Page 6
Grand Forks Library Site Traffic Analysis                                                                                           Grand Forks, ND

Grand Forks Library Site Traffic Analysis                                                                            Grand Forks, ND


4. FUTURE "BACKGROUND" TRAFFIC CONDITIONS


The "Background" traffic conditions represent future traffic levels without development of a new library.
In order to project future traffic volumes, the existing volumes are traditionally "grown", or factored up,
to the future year to replicate continued ambient "background" traffic growth. For the purposes of this
study, it was assumed that traffic levels on area roadways will increase at a rate of two percent (2%) per
year. The existing traffic volumes were factored up using this compounded annual growth rate through
2013(i.e., the anticipated "opening day" for a new library). In order to account for future increases in
traffic volumes resulting from nearby developments, peak-hour traffic volumes expected to be generated
by the planned development of the Wellness Center and Ice Arena were added to the roadway network to
derive at the future "Background" traffic volumes.

The evening peak-hour traffic volumes for the planned Wellness Center development (i.e., Wellness
Center and Ice Arena components) were estimated based on trip generation rates contained in the Institute
of Transportation Engineers (ITE) Trip Generation Handbook, 8th Edition. The resulting number of
vehicle trips is summarized in Table 2 below.

TABLE 3 - Projected Wellness Center Traffic Volumes
                      ITE Trip G e n e ratio n Du rin g W e e kd ay P e ak P M Ho u r o f A d jace n t Stre e t Traffic
                           C o rre sp o n d in g   ITE Lan d U se        1000 Sq . Fe e t       P e rce n t    P e rce n t       Trip s
 A ctu al Lan d U se
                            ITE Lan d U se             Code           G ro ss Flo o r A re a   En te rin g      Exitin g     G e n e rate d
                           He alth /Fitn e ss
 W e lln e ss C e n te r                                492          123.22 (P ro p o se d )      0.57            0.43            406
                                  C lu b
                            Re cre atio n al
     Ice A re n a                                       495          98.916 (P ro p o se d )      0.37            0.63            118
                             C o m m u n ity

Trip distribution for the wellness center and ice arena were based on current Grand Forks population
(used City of Grand Forks Land Use Map), roadways with the most direct route offering the lowest
average delay (GF-EGF MPO Functional Classification Map), and location of competing businesses
(National Independent Health Club Association Website for local fitness/health centers and Grand Forks
Park District Website for local ice arenas).

To account for the planned extension of 11th Street between 40th Avenue and 44th Avenue, appropriate
traffic reassignments were performed, reflecting the roadway network east of Washington Street. Details
of the traffic distribution assignments are shown on Figure 3. Figure 4 shows the resulting future
background traffic volumes during the PM peak hour at study intersections. The results of intersection
capacity analyses and levels of service under background traffic conditions are summarized in Tables 3A
through 3C.

Grand Forks Library Site Traffic Analysis                                                               Grand Forks, ND


5. FUTURE "TOTAL" TRAFFIC CONDITIONS


Library Sites Under Consideration

As shown on Figure 1, the proposed library improvements include consideration of three potential sites:
1) Remodeling and expansion of the existing facility (Site A), 2) Redevelopment of an existing
commercial use (Site B), and 3) Construction of a new facility within the planned Park District Wellness
Center. The characteristics of the proposed library include:

                 Total Building Area: 62,267 S.F. (proposed), 37,415 (Existing)
                 Hours of Operation: Mon. thru Thurs., 9 a.m. ­ 9 p.m.
                                      Fri. & Sat., 9 a.m. ­ 5 p.m.
                                      Sunday, 1 p.m. ­ 5 p.m.

                 # of Employees: 25 FTE (14 full-time, 34 part-time employees)

TABLE 5 - Library Generated Traffic Volumes
                 ITE Trip G e ne ration During W e e kday P e ak P M Hour of A djace nt Stre e t Traffic
                     C orre sponding      ITE Land U se        1000 Sq. Fe e t        P e rce nt   P e rce nt      Trips
 A ctual Land U se
                      ITE Land U se           C ode         G ross Floor A re a       Ente ring    Exiting      G e ne rate d
      Lib rary           Lib rary              590           37.415 (Ex istin g)        48%          52%            249
      Lib rary           Lib rary              590          62.267 (P ro p o se d )     48%          52%            396


Trip Distribution

For the purposes of this study, trips generated by the library were assigned to the area roadway network
using a directional distribution determined based on the population distribution of library patrons included
in the Library Needs study. While it was assumed that the overall distribution patterns will generally
remain the same for the three sites included in this study, appropriate adjustments were applied to reflect
adjacent roadway network and site access facilities. The resulting trip distribution patterns are shown on
Figure 5. The traffic volumes generated by the library (Table 4 above) were assigned to the roadway
network based on the distribution pattern shown on Figure 5. The resulting traffic volumes at study
intersections were then added to the total background traffic levels (Figure 4) to derive at total future
traffic volumes for year 2013 "Opening Day" and 2018 "5-Year Horizon" scenarios as shown on Figures
6 and 7, respectively.

Intersection capacity analyses were performed under future year 2013 and 2018 traffic volumes to
evaluate levels of service associated with each site. The resulting service levels are summarized in Tables
5A-5C and 6A-6C for years 2013 and 2018 respectively.




Kadrmas Lee & Jackson                                                                                              Page 17

   6. CONCLUSIONS

   This study included a comparative review of the incremental impacts on the adjacent intersections traffic
   levels of service under existing, future background (without the library), and total future (with the library)
   traffic conditions for each library site. The results are summarized graphically below.

                                                       Lane Groups with LOS Worse than C
                                                         Under Existing Traffic Conditions

                   SITE A                                                   SITE B                                        SITE C
                                                                              th
1. S Washington St/Campbell Dr ­ WB LT Lane            1. S Washington St/7 Ave ­ WB Left Lane          1. S Washington St & 40th Ave ­ WB L Lane
2. S Washington St/Campbell Dr ­ WB R Lane             2. S Washington St/7th Ave ­ EB Left Lane        2. S Washington St & 40th Ave ­ WB TR Lane
3. S Washington St/Campbell Dr ­ EB LT Lane                                                             3. S Washington St & 40th Ave ­ EB L Lane

   FIGURE 10 - Incremental Level of Service Results
   LOS of "C" or better is required at all study intersections during all analysis periods.

   SB ­ Southbound

   Kadrmas Lee & Jackson                                                                                                            Page 27
Grand Forks Library Site Traffic Analysis                                                Grand Forks, ND


While the traffic analysis results indicate a varying degree of impact associated with each site, there are
other factors that may influence the final site selection process such as land use compatibility.
Furthermore, appropriate traffic mitigation measures (e.g., operational improvements) may be necessary
to accommodate traffic volumes generated by the new library.
